acquisition.definition: The process of creating forensically sound copies of digital evidence
acquisition.context: Must be bit-for-bit exact with cryptographic hash verification for court admissibility

chain_of_custody.definition: Documentation trail proving evidence integrity from collection to court
chain_of_custody.context: Every person who handled evidence must be documented with timestamps

volatile_data.definition: Data that exists only while system is powered (RAM, active connections, running processes)
volatile_data.context: Lost at shutdown—must be acquired first during incident response

slack_space.definition: Unused space between end of file and end of cluster on disk
slack_space.context: Often contains fragments of deleted files, critical for data recovery

unallocated_space.definition: Disk sectors marked as available for reuse, may contain deleted file data
unallocated_space.context: File carving can recover deleted files from unallocated space until overwritten

hash.context: Any byte change produces completely different hash—verifies evidence unchanged

timeline.definition: Chronological sequence of events reconstructed from multiple artifact sources
timeline.context: Correlates file access, log entries, registry changes, network activity

artifact.definition: Digital evidence created by system or user activity (logs, registry, prefetch, etc.)
artifact.context: Artifacts prove actions occurred even when files are deleted

c2.definition: Command and Control server used by malware for remote attacker communication
c2.context: Identifying C2 infrastructure helps attribute attacks and block future communications

ioc.definition: Indicator of Compromise—observable evidence of system breach (IP, hash, domain, etc.)
ioc.context: IOCs enable threat hunting across multiple systems for same attack campaign

ttp.definition: Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures—characteristic attack methods used by threat actors
ttp.context: Understanding TTPs helps predict attacker next moves and implement defenses

rootkit.definition: Malware that hides its presence by subverting OS functions
rootkit.context: Detected via memory forensics comparing kernel structures vs. expected behavior

persistence.definition: Mechanisms ensuring malware survives reboot (registry Run keys, services, scheduled tasks)
persistence.context: Always check common persistence locations during malware investigations

lateral_movement.definition: Attacker spreading from initial compromised system to other network systems
lateral_movement.context: Event logs show authentication across systems, network logs show connections

privilege_escalation.definition: Gaining higher access rights than initially compromised account
privilege_escalation.context: Event logs record use of admin privileges, process creation of elevated processes

exfiltration.context: Large outbound transfers, encrypted channels, cloud uploads are red flags

file_carving.definition: Recovering files by identifying header/footer signatures without file system metadata
file_carving.context: Works on formatted drives, damaged file systems, unallocated space

mft.definition: Master File Table—NTFS structure tracking all files with metadata and timestamps
mft.context: Parsing MFT reveals deleted entries, file timelines, directory structures

prefetch.definition: Windows performance feature caching program load data, proves execution
prefetch.context: Contains first/last run time, execution count, files accessed—survives malware deletion

shimcache.definition: Windows Application Compatibility Cache tracking executables, proves file presence
shimcache.context: Records file path and last modified time even if never actually executed

shellbags.definition: Registry artifacts tracking folder access for Windows Explorer view settings
shellbags.context: Proves user accessed specific folders, even on external drives or network shares

userassist.definition: Windows registry key counting program executions with timestamps
userassist.context: ROT13-encoded keys track GUI program usage and execution counts

amcache.definition: Windows artifact logging program installations and executions
amcache.context: Newer artifact supplementing shimcache, includes SHA1 hashes of executables

jumplists.definition: Windows 7+ files tracking recently accessed documents per application
jumplists.context: Proves files were opened with specific programs, includes timestamps

sigma.definition: Generic signature format for log events, enables threat hunting rules
sigma.context: Sigma rules detect known attack patterns across different SIEM platforms

yara.definition: Pattern matching tool for malware identification via custom rules
yara.context: Rules describe malware characteristics (strings, functions, behaviors)

stix.definition: Structured Threat Information Expression—standardized threat intelligence format
stix.context: Enables automated IOC sharing between organizations and security tools

mitre_attck.definition: Framework categorizing adversary tactics and techniques
mitre_attck.context: Maps attacks to specific TTP categories for standardized threat analysis

write_blocker.definition: Hardware/software preventing writes to evidence device during acquisition
write_blocker.context: Ensures original evidence unmodified—critical for forensic soundness

forensic_soundness.definition: Evidence collection methodology ensuring court admissibility
forensic_soundness.context: Requires write protection, hash verification, and documented chain of custody

triage.definition: Rapid preliminary analysis to identify scope and severity of incident
triage.context: Focuses on high-value artifacts: memory, active connections, volatile data

dead_box.definition: Forensic analysis of powered-off system via disk imaging
dead_box.context: Safer than live analysis but loses volatile data (memory, connections)

live_forensics.definition: Evidence collection from running system without shutdown
live_forensics.context: Captures volatile data but risks alerting attacker or evidence modification
